" P U T ," said Mrs. Jones, "bridge parties DON'T cost much. Three bridge prizes, $1.50 — luncheon and incidentals, $4.00 — cigars and cigarettes, 50 cents. That's only $6.00 in all!" "Wait a minute!" said Mr. Jones. "You've forgotten all the electricity we use. I'm going to check that tonight." So he carefully took the meter reading — then just before the guests arrived for the party that night he switched on every light in the house, including the two big 300 watt indirect lights in the dining room, also the porch and basement lights and gleefully awaited results. But his high glee went glimmering — when after midnight he again checked the meter and found that with every light going he had only added 18 cents to the cost of the party! All the lighting was only 3 per cent of the other costs! WISCONSIN POWER AND LIGHT COMPANY E. A. SÖDERSTRÖM, DISTRICT MANAGER, , WIS. JULY 13, 1939 THE TOMAH JOURNAL AND MONITOR-HERALD f i . O sear H agen and family aud Mi. and Mrs. W-iiiis The money you spend with The Milwaukee Road helps pay your taxes! Your schools get a large share of the money The Milwaukee t Road pays every year in this state for taxes. Local governments and motor highways get the rest. This means that these services cost you far less than if The vMilwaukee Road were not one oi the big taxpayers. 1 The Public Pays for the Trucks9 Right-of-Way Although all railroad taxes go to maintain schools, high- ‘ ways and local governments, the commercial freight carriers insist that their license fees and gas taxes be applied only to the public highways they use for profit State surveys show that these payments by commercial freight carriers do not cover their fair share of highway costs— in fact fall far short. You and the railroads pay the difference. Railroads Essential to Industry and Agriculture Commercial motor carriers refer to employment giver and taxes paid by all trucks—including the millions of farm, private and delivery trucks^—whereas only about 5 S or 200,000 commercial trucks are m direct intercity compe- tition with the railroads. I The railroads do not complain against farm trucks, private' trucks, or delivery trucks. But the railroads do claim that highway commercial carriers, that directly compete with them, have an unfair advantage. The railroads believe it to be in the public interest that their competitors—the heavy commercial trucks that do ! most damage to the highways—should pay their own way and contribute to general taxes, as do the railroads, and thus operate on a fair competitive basis. For the sake of your community and your state, see that every transportation agency is given a square deal. In the taoe of decreasing revenues, it has steadily improved both passenger and freight service.
